intro: Paraquilegia kareliniana, commonly known as Karelin's corydalis, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Fumariaceae and is characterized by its delicate, spurred flowers that typically bloom in late spring. The plant features basal leaves that are lance-shaped and often have a hairy texture. It thrives in well-drained, rocky soils and is often found in alpine or subalpine habitats. Due to its ornamental value and rarity, it is sometimes cultivated in botanical gardens.
